# What is Basic Digital Literacy?

## Introduction

In today's educational environment, digital literacy is as essential as traditional reading and writing skills. For Excel High School students, possessing basic digital literacy is a foundational requirement that enables successful participation in online courses and completion of academic work. Before diving into specific course content, it's important to ensure you have the fundamental digital skills needed to navigate your educational journey effectively. This lesson will outline the core digital competencies every Excel High School student should possess, creating a common baseline from which all your coursework can proceed.

## Core Concept 1: Defining Basic Digital Literacy for Excel High School Students

Basic digital literacy at Excel High School refers to the essential technical skills required to effectively participate in online learning. These are the foundational abilities that allow you to access, navigate, and engage with course materials, submit assignments, and communicate with instructors and peers in a virtual environment.

Digital literacy encompasses more than just knowing how to turn on a computer. It involves competently using digital tools to find, evaluate, create, and communicate information. At Excel High School, we consider students digitally literate when they can independently:

- Navigate digital learning platforms and access course materials
- Communicate effectively through digital channels
- Create and manage digital documents for coursework
- Troubleshoot basic technical issues
- Practice safe and responsible online behavior

These skills aren't just academic requirements—they're practical life skills that will serve you well beyond your time at Excel High School. In today's increasingly digital world, these competencies are essential for college readiness, career preparation, and everyday functioning in society.

## Core Concept 2: Essential Digital Skills Checklist

Before beginning your coursework at Excel High School, ensure you possess these specific digital skills that form the foundation of your online learning experience:

### Navigating the Internet
- Competently use web browsers (Chrome, Firefox, Safari, etc.)
- Understand and use web addresses (URLs)
- Efficiently search for information using search engines
- Navigate between multiple web pages and tabs
- Bookmark important websites
- Distinguish between reliable and unreliable online sources
- Understand basic internet safety and privacy concepts

### Email Communication
- Create and access an email account
- Compose and send professional emails
- Reply to and forward messages
- Organize emails using folders or labels
- Attach files to emails
- Download and save email attachments
- Use email etiquette appropriate for academic settings

### Document Creation and Editing
- Create new documents using word processing software
- Format text (font styles, sizes, colors, etc.)
- Insert and modify images, tables, and other elements
- Save documents in appropriate file formats
- Share documents electronically
- Print documents when necessary
- Work with specific applications such as:
  - Google Docs in Google Workspace
  - Microsoft Word, PowerPoint, and Excel in Microsoft Office
  - Writer, Impress, and Calc in OpenOffice/LibreOffice

## Core Concept 3: Applying Digital Literacy Skills in Your Coursework

Digital literacy skills are not standalone abilities but practical tools you'll use throughout your Excel High School experience. Here's how these fundamental skills translate to academic success:

When taking courses at Excel High School, you'll regularly need to:
- Navigate the learning management system to access course modules, assignments, and resources
- Download course materials and upload completed assignments
- Communicate with instructors via email, including sending questions with document attachments
- Create well-formatted documents for assignments and projects
- Collaborate with peers on group projects using shared documents

These basic digital literacy skills create the foundation upon which more advanced technical skills can be built. As you progress through your courses, you may develop additional competencies such as creating spreadsheets, designing presentations, or using specialized software relevant to specific subjects.

Remember that digital literacy is not static—it evolves as technology changes. Being open to learning new digital tools and adapting to technological updates is an important aspect of maintaining your digital literacy throughout your academic journey and beyond.

## Over to You
1. Which of the basic digital literacy skills do you feel most confident about, and which might you need to strengthen before beginning your coursework?
2. How might improving your digital literacy skills benefit you beyond your academic work at Excel High School?
3. What strategies could you use to improve any digital literacy skills you currently find challenging?

## Check Your Understanding

1. What is considered the most fundamental aspect of basic digital literacy for Excel High School students?
   - A. Creating complex spreadsheets
   - B. Programming in multiple languages
   - C. Navigating the internet, using email, and creating documents
   - D. Setting up computer networks

2. When attaching a document to an email, which skill set are you primarily using?
   - A. Internet navigation
   - B. Email communication
   - C. Document creation
   - D. Hardware installation

3. Why does Excel High School emphasize basic digital literacy skills before beginning coursework?
   - A. To make enrollment more difficult
   - B. To satisfy government regulations
   - C. To ensure students have the foundational skills needed across all courses
   - D. To promote specific software brands

## Summary

Basic digital literacy is the foundation upon which your Excel High School education is built. The core skills of navigating the internet, communicating via email, and creating/editing documents in standard office suites are essential prerequisites for success in all your courses. By confirming you possess these fundamental abilities before beginning coursework, you establish a solid baseline that allows you to focus on learning subject matter rather than struggling with technical requirements. As you continue your education, these skills will develop further, preparing you not only for academic success but for effective participation in our increasingly digital world.
